EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Oiltanking Texas City

Marine Terminal

2800 Loop 197 South

Texas City, Texas 77590



|====================|

|RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN|

|====================|



Oiltanking Texas City, L.P. (Oiltanking Texas City) operates a marine terminal that stores chemicals including hydrocarbons, specialty polymers, solvents, intermediates, monomers and industrial products.  Processes occurring at Oiltanking Texas City are barge and tanker loading/unloading, storage, transportation and distribution of chemicals.  U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulation Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68), Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, requires Oiltanking Texas City to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule because the quantities of propylene, vinyl acetate monomer, butane, isopentane, pentane, 1-pentene, and ethylenediamine stored onsite exceed threshold quantities.



The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA approved chemical release prevention program.  In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP covered facilities to update its Risk Management Program Plan (RMP Plan) at certain intervals, among which is the onsite presence of a new chemical in an amount greater than its threshold quantity.  The initial RMP Plan for Oiltanking Texas City was submitted to the EPA in November 2004.  The June 2007 revision included updates to terminology to more clearly reflect operations at Oiltanking Texas City, stylistic and grammatical corrections, and expansions of the assumptions made and techniques employed in the evaluation of release quantities, release rates, and impacts.  The August 2007 revision contains changes and updates that resulted from an EPA RMP inspection in June 2007.  This September 2008 revision contains changes and updates that resulted from the Permit by Rule (PBR) 83949 authorization of three new products that conta

in isopentane, pentane, and 1-pentene.  Oiltanking Texas City currently holds the following RMP-regulated substances above threshold quantities:



Regulated Chemical    CAS Number    Characteristic    Threshold (lbs)

Propylene        115-07-1    Flammable gas    10,000

Butane            106-97-8    Flammable gas    10,000

1-pentene        109-67-1    Flammable gas    10,000

Pentane            109-66-0    Flammable gas    10,000

Isopentane        78-78-4        Flammable gas    10,000

Vinyl Acetate Monomer    108-05-4    Toxic chemical    15,000

Ethylenediamine        107-15-3    Toxic chemical    20,000





|================================|

|KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS|

|================================|



40 CFR 68 requires all facilities, subject to the rule, to conduct an offsite consequence analysis to provide information about any potential consequences of an accidental chemical release to the public and state and federal environmental agencies.  Offsite consequence analyses are essential in identifying potential hazards of accidental release.  The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) comprises 2 elements, a worst-case scenario and an alternative release scenario.



|==========================|

|FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY|

|==========================|



Oiltanking Texas City, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical releases that resulted in any known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.   



|======================================|

|ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES|

|======================================|



The plans for evacuation and accounting for personnel after an evacuation at Oiltanking Texas City are located onsite for all personnel to review.



If a release occurs, arrangements are described in the Emergency Response Plan for notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.



Oiltanking Texas City is committed to operate and maintain its facility in a safe and environmentally friendly man

ner. Oiltanking Texas City complies with the rules and regulations set forth by the U.S. EPA Risk Management Plan to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings.



Oiltanking Texas City designed its accident prevention program to comply with the EPA RMP rule.  Oiltanking Texas City incorporates elements addressing the following:



* Equipment Design ? Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.



* Process Safety Information ? Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.



* Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) ? PHAs are conducted every three (3) years to identify major process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.



* Episodic Risk Management ? Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards which could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques.



* Operational Safety Standards ? Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards.



* Operating Procedures ? Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are maintained up-to-date.



* Operator Training/Certification Program ? The plant has a training and testing program, which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.



* Technical Staff Training and Support ? Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a day to support operations.



* Maintenance Procedures ? The plant has specific procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.



* Maintenance Training ? The plant trains p

ersons who perform routine or complex maintenance tasks on process equipment.



* Mechanical Integrity Program ? Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.



* Management of Change (MOC) ? The plant has a management system to ensure that modified facilities and processes will be safe to operate.



* Pre-startup Safety Review ? Reviews are conducted just prior to startup to ensure that modified facilities and processes are safe for operation.



* Incident Investigation ? The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents are properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) that are needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.



* Employee Participation ? The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention program elements.



* Hot Work Permit ? The plant has a procedure to ensure that welding, cutting, and brazing are safely performed in areas where flammables or combustible material may be present.



* Contractor Safety Program ? The plant has a procedure to ensure that contractors are properly trained and perform their work in compliance with safety requirements.



* Compliance Audits ? Periodic corporate and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and corporate requirements.



* Operational Safety Program ? Oiltanking has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed above are implemented at every Oiltanking location.  This program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements.



These general prevention elements are parts of an overall management system to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Oiltanking Texas City and its employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set, and have

specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.





|==========================|

|EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM|

|==========================|



Oiltanking Texas City maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including fire or explosion and is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the facility.



The procedures address all aspects of emergency response including:



* Proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures.

* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation.

* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.

* Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.



Oiltanking Texas City maintains a trained emergency squad to handle fire, explosions, toxic vapor releases, spills, and medical emergencies.  The facility trains and drills with local emergency responders to enhance their skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release.  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.  The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Galveston County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).





|=================================|

|Planned Changes to Improve Safety|

|=================================|



Oiltanking Texas City continually strives to improve its safety-related systems.  Its policies and procedures provide the most efficient means to minimize environmental impacts onsite and to the public.  Oiltanking Texas City also continues to improve by implemen

ting an incident investigation database to monitor potential risks of future incidents.  These improvements, along with monthly reviews of current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents.
